column4: If left empty, the letting log will be assigned to the account used to upload the log.
column5: General needs housing includes both self-contained and shared housing without support or specific adaptations. Supported housing includes direct access hostels, group homes, residential care and nursing homes.
column6:
Scheme code. Include the 'S' at the beginning if it has one.

You can find the scheme code on the CORE service under 'Schemes', either by searching for the specific scheme or downloading a csv.
column7:
Location code.

You can find the location code on the CORE service under 'Schemes', either by searching for the specific location or downloading a csv.
column8: If the property was previously being used as temporary accommodation, then answer 'no'.
column14: This is how you usually refer to this tenancy on your own systems.
column15: This is how you usually refer to this property on your own systems.
column16: Make sure the lead tenant has seen or been given access to the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government (MHCLG) privacy notice before completing this log. This is a legal requirement under data protection legislation.
column17:
Internal transfer - Where a tenant moved from one social housing property to another property. Their landlord may be the same or may have changed.

Renewal of a fixed term tenancy - to the same tenant in the same property, except if was previously used as temporary accommodation.
column18: This is the rent type of the previous tenancy in this property.
column19:
The Unique Property Reference Number (UPRN) is a unique number system created by Ordnance Survey and used by housing providers and various industries across the UK. An example UPRN is 10010457355.
The UPRN may not be the same as the property reference assigned by your organisation.
column24: Combined with field 22 it should be a postcode which lies within the local authority given in field 25.
column25: Combined with field 21 it should be a postcode which lies within the local authority given in field 25.
column29: This is whether someone who uses a wheelchair is able to make full use of all of the property’s rooms and facilities, including use of both inside and outside space, and entering and exiting the property.
column30: If shared accommodation, enter the number of bedrooms occupied by this household. A bedsit has 1 bedroom.
column31:
Date the property was (legally/contractually) available to let, or for:
- re-lets: the day after previous tenant’s contract end
- new-builds: the day the landlord legally owned the property ('completion date’)
- new conversions or acquisitions: the completion date, or the day after any rehabilitation work ended
- new leases: the day the landlord got contractual property rights, and could let it out to tenants.
column34: Major repairs are works that could not be reasonably carried out with a tenant living at the property. For example, structural repairs.
column37:
This includes retirement living, sheltered housing and extra care housing. There is no national set limit for “older people”, please answer based on your own policies.

Extra care housing is for tenants with medium to high care and support needs, often with 24 hour access to support staff provided by an agency registered with the Care Quality Commission.
column38: This is where two or more people are named on the tenancy agreement.
column39:
If the tenancy has an ‘introductory period’ answer ‘yes’.
You should submit a CORE log at the beginning of the starter tenancy or introductory period, with the best information you have at the time. You do not need to submit a log when a tenant later rolls onto the main tenancy.
column40: This is about the main tenancy after any starter or introductory period. See specification for definitions.
column42: Do not include the starter or introductory period. The minimum period is 2 years for social or affordable rent general needs logs. You do not need to submit CORE logs for these types of tenancies if they are shorter than 2 years.
column43: This is the household member who does the most paid work. If several people do the same amount of paid work, it's the oldest household member.
column44: This should be however they personally choose to identify from the options below. This may or may not be the same as their biological sex or the sex they were assigned at birth.

column99: The tenant's ‘last settled home' is their last long-standing home. For tenants who had temporary accommodation, sleeping rough or otherwise homeless, their last settled home is where they were living previously.

column107: Households may be given ‘reasonable preference’ for social housing under one or more specific category by the local authority. This is also known as ‘priority need’.
column113: Where available vacant properties are advertised and applicants are able to bid for specific properties.
column114: Where a common system agreed between a group of housing providers is used to determine applicants' priority for housing.
column115: Where a single waiting list is used by a group of housing providers to receive and process housing applications. Providers may use different approaches to determine priority.
column116: Where the 'access category' or another descriptor of whether an available vacant property meets a range of access needs is displayed to applicants during the allocations process.
column120: Include any income after tax from employment, pensions, and Universal Credit. Don't include National Insurance (NI) contributions and tax, housing benefit, child benefit, or council tax support.
column121: This is about when the tenant is in their new let. If they are unsure about the situation for their new let and their financial and working situation hasn’t changed significantly, answer based on what housing-related benefits they currently receive.
column123: If rent is charged on the property then answer Yes, even if tenants do not pay it themselves.
column125: This is the amount paid before any charges are added for services (for example, hot water or cleaning). Households may receive housing benefit or Universal Credit towards basic rent.
column126: For example, cleaning. Households may get household benefits towards the service charge.
column127: For example heating or hot water. This doesn’t include housing benefit or Universal Credit.
